title: 106_s2310
content: The "Firearms Dealer Penalty Flexibility Act of 2000" allows for the suspension of a firearms dealer's license and imposes civil penalties. Section 923 of title 18, United States Code, allows the Secretary to suspend or revoke a license or impose civil penalties up to $10,000 for willful violations of firearm regulations. The Secretary has the authority to suspend or revoke a license, impose civil penalties up to $10,000, or compromise liability for willful violations of firearm regulations. The Secretary has the authority to compromise, mitigate, or remit liability for willful violations of firearm regulations. Any action taken by the Secretary can only be reviewed as provided in subsection (f), which outlines the rights of applicants and licensees in case of license denial, revocation, suspension, or civil penalty assessment. If the Secretary denies a license application, revokes or suspends a license, or assesses a civil penalty, written notice must be provided to the affected party stating the specific grounds for the action. The Secretary must provide written notice of the specific grounds for denying, revoking, or suspending a license, or assessing a civil penalty. An appeal process is available upon request of the aggrieved party. If the Secretary denies an application, revokes or suspends a license, or assesses a civil penalty, a hearing can be requested by the aggrieved party for review. The hearing will be held at a convenient location. If the Secretary decides not to reverse the decision after the hearing, an appeal process is available. After a hearing, if the Secretary decides not to reverse the decision to deny an application, revoke or suspend a license, or assess a civil penalty, the aggrieved party will be notified of the decision and has a 60-day period to appeal. The Secretary's decision can be appealed by the aggrieved party within a 60-day period by filing a petition with the district court for a de novo judicial review. The aggrieved party can appeal the Secretary's decision within 60 days by filing a petition in the judicial district where they reside or have a principal place of business for a de novo judicial review. The court may consider any evidence submitted by the parties in the proceeding. The court may consider any evidence submitted by the parties, regardless of whether it was presented at the hearing. If the court determines the Secretary's decision was unauthorized, they will order the Secretary to take action. The court may order the Secretary to comply with its judgment if the Secretary was not authorized to deny, revoke, suspend, or assess penalties. If a license is suspended or revoked, the Secretary must stay the action upon request pending appeal. Upon request, the Secretary shall stay the effective date of license revocation, suspension, or penalty assessment pending an appeal. Section 925(b) of title 18, United States Code, is amended to terminate a firearms dealer's license upon felony conviction.
